questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a history of mitral stenosis is brought unconscious to the ER. Her pulse rate is 140 bpm and BP is 80/60 mmHg. An ECG is obtained and is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows an irregularly irregular rhythm with absent P waves, which is consistent with atrial fibrillation. Since the patient is hemodynamically compromised (hypotension), synchronized cardioversion is the most appropriate management.

Urgent electrical cardioversion is indicated if a patient with AF has a shock or severe hypotension, pulmonary edema, or ongoing myocardial infarction. Although there is a risk of potential thromboembolism if the patient has not been put on anticoagulation before, the need for rate control outweighs this risk. In these patients, control of the heart rate is achieved using IV β-blockers or calcium channel blockers (like verapamil or diltiazem). Additionally, they are also given subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin as soon as possible.

In hemodynamically stable patients with AF of >48 hours duration or unknown duration, there is a high risk of formation of a thrombus in the left atrium. If the patients are cardioverted at this stage, this thrombus can embolize into the systemic circulation, leading to end organ damage, such as stroke. Therefore, for these patients, any of the following two management strategies can be followed:

  • Give anticoagulation for 3 weeks → cardioversion (pharmacological or electrical) → continue anticoagulation for 4 more weeks
  • Start anticoagulation and do transesophageal echocardiography → if the thrombus is absent, do cardioversion (pharmacological or electrical) → continue anticoagulation for 4 more weeks. If a thrombus is present, then cardioversion is delayed by 3 weeks

Direct-acting oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are preferred over warfarin for anticoagulation. However, warfarin is the preferred drug if the patient has a mechanical prosthetic valve, advanced CKD, or moderate-severe mitral stenosis.

Apart from anticoagulation, the most important aspect of the treatment of chronic AF is rate control. The drugs used for this are β blockers (such as metoprolol) and calcium channel blockers (such as diltiazem and verapamil). Reversion to sinus rhythm can be done electrically or using medications. Pharmacological cardioversion can be done using ibutilide, dofetilide and amiodarone (class III antiarryhthmics) or flecainide and propafenone (class Ic drugs).

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with the abnormality depicted in the given ECG?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows inverted P waves, negative QRS in lead I, and reversal of normal r wave progression. The condition associated with these findings is dextrocardia. 

Dextrocardia is the abnormal position of the heart on the right side of the chest or in the midline. It may be seen as an isolated condition or as a part of situs inversus, where the other organs are also inverted in position. Situs inversus is associated with Kartagener's syndrome (a triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis). 

Findings suggestive of dextrocardia:

  • Inverted P waves in Lead I and aVL
  • Negative QRS complex and T wave in Lead I
  • Lead I: inversion of all complexes, aka ‘global negativity’ i.e. inverted P wave, negative QRS, inverted T wave
  • Reversal of normal r-wave progression across the precordium

Most patients are asymptomatic. Some may present with varying symptoms due to other coexisting congenital diseases. 

Other options:

Option A - Cardiac tamponade would present with reduced amplitude of the QRS complexes and electrical alternans on the ECG.

 

Option B - Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease would present as multifocal atrial tachycardia (variable P wave morphology) and right ventricular hypertrophy on ECG. 

 

Option C - Type 1 Atrioventricular block would have prolonged PR intervals.

questions.text: While taking ward rounds, you come across the ECG of a patient, and changes include ST-depression, flat T waves, and prominent U waves. Which of the following can cause such an ECG?
questions.solution:
Based on the ECG changes described, the likely diagnosis is hypokalemia. Hypokalemia may be caused by a rapid infusion of insulin. Insulin promotes Na+/K+ATPase-mediated cellular uptake of K+, leading to hypokalemia.

Hypokalemia is defined as a plasma concentration of K+ <3.5 meq/L. Common causes include metabolic alkalosis, insulin infusions, diarrhea, use of diuretics, starvation, and β2-agonists. It can also be seen after massive blood transfusions and in cystic fibrosis. It affects the cardiac, skeletal, and intestinal cells. It can lead to arrhythmias and intestinal ileus and increase the risk for rhabdomyolysis.

ECG changes include ST depression, prominent U waves, and prolonged repolarization.

Other options:

Option A: Vitamin A can cause hypercalcemia. It will show a shortening of the QT interval and a decrease in the ST segment duration in ECG. 

Options B and C: ACE inhibitors and non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis cause hyperkalemia. Acidemia is associated with cellular uptake of H+ and an associated efflux of K+; it is thought that this effective K+/H+ exchange serves to help maintain extracellular pH.

ECG changes in hyperkalemia. Different changes are seen according to the levels of potassium.

  • Tall peaked T waves are present when the serum potassium levels are 5.5–6.5 mmol/L. 
  • Loss of P waves is seen when the concentration is between 6.5–7.5 mmol/L.
  • Widened QRS complex is seen when the concentration is between 7.0–8.0 mmol/L
  • Sine wave pattern when concentration is >8.0 mmol/L

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient is undergoing perioperative risk assessment for bariatric surgery. His BMI is 42 kg/m2. On physical examination, his pulse rate is 74/minute, blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 17/minute. He has a history of hypertension on medications, chronic hepatitis C, and a myocardial infarction (MI) 6 months ago. His ECG strip is shown below. What is his American Society of Anaesthesiologists (ASA) classification?
questions.solution:
The image shows an ECG strip taken from a patient with an implanted ventricular pacemaker.

The cardinal manifestation of pacing on a surface ECG is the stimulation artifact. In ventricular pacing, the vertical pacing spike will precede the QRS complex. Ventricular pacing also yields a wide QRS complex with an LBBB pattern.

This patient has a BMI >=40 kg/m2, hypertension on medications, chronic hepatitis C, a history of MI 6 months ago (> 3 months), and a pacemaker, which places him in the category of ASA III.
ASA grading is a physical status examination that strongly correlates with the perioperative risk. 

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA-PS Classification:

Class Definition Examples, including, but not limited to:
I A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
II A patient with mild systemic disease Current smoker, well-controlled DM and HTN
III A patient with severe systemic disease Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD or stents.
IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents
V A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Ruptured abdominal, thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect
VI A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes

questions.text:
Match the following:
  1. First-degree heart block
  2. Mobitz type 1 heart block
  3. Mobitz type 2 heart block
  4. Complete heart block
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, and 4-b.

The different types of heart blocks are:

First Degree Heart Block: It occurs due to slowing of conduction through the AV junction. It is characterized by prolonged PR > 0.2s and equal RR intervals.

Second Degree Heart Block: It occurs due to the intermittent failure of electrical impulse conduction from the atrium to the ventricle. It is characterized by a missed QRS. It is of two types:

  • Mobitz type 1 (Wenckebach) occurs due to the decremental conduction of electrical impulses in the AV node. It is characterized by a progressive PR elongation leading to an eventual drop in the QRS complex. This may be seen in young athletes.
  • Mobitz type 2 occurs in the distal or infra-His conduction system and is often associated with intraventricular conduction delays. It is characterized by an intermittent failure of conduction of the p wave without any change in the preceding impulses. On ECG, there is a fixed PR interval and missed QRS.

Third Degree Heart Block/Complete Heart Block: It occurs when none of the impulses from the atria are conducted to the ventricles. It is characterized by

  • Escape rhythm
  • RR equal, PP equal
  • P waves > QRS waves
  • No relationship between P & QRS

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: An elderly male patient was brought to the hospital with complaints of palpitations and dizziness. His vitals are stable, and the ECG shows the following. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
In the given ECG, the presence of narrow-complex regular tachycardia and P-waves occurring after QRS complexes, known as retro P waves or pseudo-r' waves (especially prominent in lead V1) point to a diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). In this patient, the next step would be the administration of IV adenosine.

PSVT is an arrhythmia characterized by a sudden onset and offset with rapid ventricular response. It includes atrioventricular nodal reentry tachycardia, junctional tachycardia, and AV reentry tachycardia.

Initial management of PSVT is by vagal maneuvers such as carotid massage, Valsalva maneuver, and breathing against pressure in a syringe. Vagal maneuvers increase the parasympathetic discharge, thus slowing down the conduction through the AV node and terminating the arrhythmia. Carotid sinus massage is avoided if the patient has a carotid bruit. 

If this method is ineffective, intravenous adenosine is used. It can terminate the majority of PSVT episodes by blocking the conduction at the AV node. If adenosine is also ineffective in terminating the arrhythmia, IV β blockers (esmolol, metoprolol) and IV non-DHP calcium channel blockers (verapamil and diltiazem) are used. Note that IV adenosine (option B) is preferred over β blockers and non-DHP CCBs (options A and D) for terminating PSVT because of its rapid onset, excellent success rate, and minimal negative inotropic effect.

Electrical cardioversion (option C) is done if the patient is hemodynamically unstable or if PSVT does not respond to any of the other methods mentioned above.

The flowchart given below summarizes the treatment of PSVT:

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: A 46-year-old male patient came to the emergency department with fever and severe constrictive chest pain that worsened with deep inspiration and on lying down. He had a myocardial infarction 2 weeks back. A pericardial friction sound was audible at the lower left sternal border. The electrocardiogram is given below.  Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is due to an infection in the pericardium
Aspirin is given as first line treatment
Colchicine can be used in treatment

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a post-myocardial infarction (MI) patient presenting with pleuritic chest pain, fever, malaise, pericardial rub on auscultation, and the ECG given above showing diffuse ST-segment elevation with upward concavity are suggestive of Dressler syndrome.

Dressler syndrome/post-myocardial infarction syndrome is an autoimmune condition (option B) with inflammation of the pericardium. It presents as pleuritic chest pain, fever, malaise, and sometimes a pleuritic rub and effusion. The ECG findings include PR segment depression or ST-segment elevation. It commonly occurs 1–8 weeks after MI (option A). However, it can recur over months.

Treatment:

  • First-line therapy consists of aspirin 650 mg (option C) every 4 hours with NSAIDs like Ibuprofen or Indomethacin
  • Colchicine (option D) enhances the response to NSAIDs and prevents recurrence
  • Glucocorticosteroids and NSAIDs are best avoided in patients with Dressler syndrome within 4 weeks of STEMI as they may impair infarct healing, cause ventricular rupture, and increase coronary vascular resistance

Complications of myocardial infarction:

  • Myocardial rupture
  • Contractile dysfunction
  • Arrhythmia: Ventricular fibrillation is the most common arrhythmia within one hour of MI
  • Supraventricular tachycardia
  • Heart block
  • Pericarditis: occur even 48 hours after MI
  • Dressler syndrome or post-MI syndrome: 2-3 weeks after a transmural MI
  • Ventricular aneurysm
  • Progressive late heart failure (chronic IHD)
  • Infarct expansion associated with mural thrombus
  • Papillary muscle dysfunction

Myocardial rupture: Various forms of cardiac rupture typically occur when there is transmural necrosis of a ventricle. 

Rupture of the left ventricular free wall
  • Most common
  • 3-7 days after MI
  • Hemopericardium and cardiac tamponade
Rupture of the ventricular septum
  • Less common
  • Acute ventricular septal defect (VSD) and left-to-right shunting
Papillary muscle rupture
  • Least common
  • Severe mitral regurgitation

questions.text: A 5-year-old patient is undergoing an abdominal laparoscopy under general anesthesia. During the surgery, the anesthetist notices that the monitor shows the findings below when the surgeon is manipulating the peritoneum. The blood pressure is 94/60 mm Hg. Which of the following is not true about this condition?

choices.text: Parasympathetic response via the vagal nerves is responsible for this condition
Intra-abdominal pressure should be 12–15 mmHg to avoid this response
Anticholinergic agents have no role in management of such cases
Same response may be seen while manipulating the extra ocular muscles in strabismus surgery

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a vagal reflex that occurs in patients during abdominal laparotomy. The given ECG shows sinus bradycardia in this patient with an approximate heart rate of 40 bpm. Anticholinergics like glycopyrrolate may be used in the medical management of this condition. 

Vagal responses:

  • Surgical manipulation may precipitate vagal responses (option A). Common examples would include bradycardia during manipulation of extraocular muscles (option D) during strabismus surgery and peritoneal manipulation during laparotomy or laparoscopy
  • Bradycardia leading to cardiac arrest has been a recognized complication of laparoscopy since its development
  • Peritoneal stretch due to insufflation leads to an increase in vagal tone. This is seen in a large number of gynecological and general surgery cases
  • The rate of CO2 insufflation is an important causative factor for the vagal responses. The fast and rapid rate has led to a strong response in many cases. To prevent this, the initial rate of insufflation is recommended to be maintained below 15 L/min
  • Certain anesthetic agents, such as propofol, can lead to bradycardia and should be avoided on a case-by-case basis
  • The intra-abdominal pressure should be limited to 12–15 mmHg (option B) to avoid such events

Management includes:

  • Immediately notify the surgeon and ask for temporary cessation of surgery until the heart rate increases
  • Providing adequate ventilation, oxygenation, and depth of anesthesia 
  • Administration of IV atropine 10 mg/kg and mild chest compressions can also be done to allow the atropine to circulate
  • Transcutaneous/transvenous pacing may be used in refractory cases

Note: In recalcitrant episodes, a local anesthetic can be injected into the rectus muscles.

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Pediatric Anesthesia

  • The narrowest part of the larynx in the infant is at the cricoid level, in administering anesthesia this may lead to Laryngeal edema, trauma to sub epiglottic region, post-operative stridor.
  • Neonatal circumcision is done under General anesthesia.
  • Oculocardiac reflex:
    • Trigemino-vagal-reflex
    • Causes-strabismus surgery, cataract surgery, enucleation, ocular trauma, retinal detachment surgery.
    • Manifestation-bradycardia (most common)
    • Treatment-temporary cessation surgery until heart rate increases, IV Atropine.
  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy :
    • High risk for malignant hyperthermia so succinyl choline and halothane should be avoided
    • Choice of anesthesia is propofol, nitrous oxide for maintenance.

questions.text: Osborn J waves are not seen in :
questions.solution:
Osborn J waves are not seen in hyperkalemia.

Osborn J waves are the distinctive convex elevations of the J point as seen in the image.

It consists of an extra deflection on the ECG at the terminal junction of the QRS complex and the beginning of the ST-segment takeoff.

  • Usually, it occurs when the core body temperature falls below 90°F (32°C), seen in conditions such as hypothermia (option A) secondary to severe hypothyroidism (option B)
  • Results from an exaggerated outward potassium current leading to repolarization abnormality
  • They can also be found in other conditions, such as hypercalcemia (option C)
  • Other causes include brain injury, subarachnoid hemorrhage, cardiopulmonary arrest from oversedation, vasospastic angina, and idiopathic ventricular fibrillation

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presented with a prolonged history of fainting spells and palpitations. He is a known case of Brugada syndrome and has been started on quinidine for the same, after which he developed a cardiac rhythm, as shown in the ECG given below. Which of the following could be the diagnosis?

WPW: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome

AVNRT: Atrioventricular nodal reentry tachycardia

choices.text: Torsades  de pointes with QT prolongation

questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the given scenario is torsades de pointes with QT interval prolongation.

Quinidine can cause polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, or torsades de pointes, which has been shown in the given ECG. Quinidine is often used in the management of patients with Brugada syndrome, as a class I antiarrhythmic agent (Ia).

Torsades de pointes, which means “twisting of the points,” is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia characterized by the twisting of the QRS axis around the baseline and a polymorphic appearance. This rhythm is most commonly seen in association with hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia. There is QT interval prolongation in the ECG due to a non-uniform delay in repolarization.

Other cause of torsades de pointes:

  • Drugs like quinidine, procainamide, disopyramide, and phenothiazine (amiodarone is rarely associated with torsades de pointes because the delay in repolarization induced by it is uniform)
  • Bradycardia
  • Acute ischemia or infarction

Management:

  • Discontinue the offending drug
  • Correct electrolyte abnormalities, pH, and hypoxia
  • Magnesium sulfate infusion 
  • Increase the heart rate with electrical pacing, isoproterenol infusion, or intravenous atropine 

If the patient is hemodynamically stable, IV MgSO4 is the treatment of choice. IV MgSO4 is highly effective for both treatment and prevention of the recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that trigger torsades de pointes.

If the patient is hemodynamically unstable, then immediate defibrillation should be done.

Brugada syndrome is a rare syndrome characterized by >0.2 mV of ST-segment elevation and negative T-wave in more than one anterior precordial lead (V1–V3).

Episodes of syncope or cardiac arrest are common due to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT) in the absence of structural heart disease, as in Brugada syndrome. Cardiac arrest may occur during sleep or be provoked by febrile illness. Males are more commonly affected than females. Mutations involving cardiac sodium channels are identified in a quarter of cases. Quinidine has been used successfully to suppress frequent episodes of VT.

Related Pearl: Etiology of Torsade De Pointes

Acquired prolongation of QT interval

Electrolyte abnormalities

  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypocalcemia

Drugs

  • Antiarrhythmic drugs
    • Class IA: Quinidine, disopyramide, procainamide
    • Class III: Sotalol, amiodarone (QT prolongation common but torsade ventricular tachycardia is rare), ibutilide, dofetilide, almokalant
  • Antibiotics
    • Macrolides: Erythromycin, clarithromycin, azithromycin
    • Fluoroquinolones: Levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, gatifloxacin
    • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
    • Clindamycin
    • Pentamidine
    • Chloroquine
    • Antifungals: Ketoconazole, itraconazole
    • Antivirals
    • Antipsychotics
    • Antihistamines

Related Pearl: ECG patterns of various ventricular arrhythmias

Ventricular tachycardia

 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QTc prolongation- Torsades de pointes

 

Ventricular flutter

 

Ventricular fibrillation

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: Identify the rhythm abnormality in the ECG strip:
questions.solution:
The ECG depicts monomorphic VT.

Monomorphic VT has the same QRS complex from beat to beat, indicating that the activation sequence is the same from beat to beat and that each beat likely originates from the same source. Other features include:

  • Rapid heart rate (> 100 bpm)
  • Broad QRS complexes (> 120 ms)

Related Pearl: ECG patterns of various ventricular arrhythmias

Ventricular tachycardia

 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QTc prolongation- Torsades de pointes

 

Ventricular flutter

 

Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: A student was asked to record ECG by using bipolar limb leads. The below image shows the arrangement of the bipolar electrodes and the potentials recorded across lead I and lead II. What is the potential recorded across lead III?
questions.solution:
According to Einthoven’s law, the potential recorded across lead III is +0.7 mV.

Einthoven’s Law: Einthoven’s law states that if the ECGs are recorded simultaneously with the three limb leads, the sum of the potentials recorded in leads I and III will equal the potential in lead II.

Lead I potential + Lead III potential = Lead II potential

Lead III = Lead II – Lead I = (1.2-0.5) = +0.7 mV.

Note: Einthoven's triangle is an imaginary triangle drawn around the area of the heart. It is formed by the arrangement of three bipolar limb leads (the two arms and left leg).

Related Pearl: ECG Leads

LA – Left arm: RA – Right arm: LL – Left leg: LF – Left foot

  • Limb leads measure the electrical activity in the frontal plane
  • Chest leads measure the electrical activity in the horizontal plane


Limb Lead Location Augmented limb leads Location Chest leads Location
+ -
I LA

  RA aVF LF +ve V1 4th intercostal space. just to the right of the sternum
II LL

  RA aVL LA +ve V2 4th intercostal space. just to the left of the sternum
III LL

 LA  aVR RA +ve V3 midway between V2 and V4
  V4 Midclavicular line. fifth intercostal
V5 Anterior axillary line, same level as V4
V6 Midaxillary line, the same level as V4 and V5

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the clinic after he experienced palpitations. He has a history of ischemic heart disease.  His ECG findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is likely to be seen on physical examination of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows atrial fibrillation. On physical examination of his jugular venous pressure, absent 'a' waves will be noted. 

The following features in the ECG strip suggest the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation:

  • Presence of fibrillatory 'f' waves is indicative of uncoordinated atrial activation. Normal morphology P waves (indicative of normal atrial contraction) are absent
  • The QRS complex duration is <120 ms, which is normal. A narrow QRS complex indicates that the impulses are originating from the atria
  • R waves (QRS complex) occur irregularly, indicative of a variable RR interval. The rhythm is irregular (the pace is set by the refractory period of the AV node)

The 'a' wave is the first peak on a JVP tracing. It represents the atrial contraction (atrial systole). The rapid impulses of atrial fibrillation do not allow enough time for atrial filling and atrial contraction, leading to absent 'a' waves on JVP. 

In acute atrial fibrillation with hemodynamic instability, electrical or chemical cardioversion is the first step. The latter is done by intravenous administration of class III antiarrhythmic - ibutilide. In a stable patient, ventricular rate control is the primary aim. This is done by intravenous or oral administration of beta-blockers. Calcium channel blockers such as verapamil and diltiazem can also be used. 

If the current episode duration is >48 hours, cardioversion can precipitate thromboembolic complications. In such cases, cardioversion should be carried out only after 3 weeks of anticoagulation. It has to be continued for 4 weeks after cardioversion. Another option is to evaluate the presence of a thrombus in the left atrial appendage. This can be done either by transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) or high-resolution CT.

If the duration is <48 hours and there are no high-risk factors, cardioversion can be done. CHA2DS2-VASc scoring system is used to assess stroke risk. 

Warfarin is recommended in patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves who present with atrial fibrillation. In mitral stenosis, thrombi arise frequently from the dilated left atrium. Atrial fibrillation in the absence of mitral stenosis is known as nonvalvular atrial fibrillation. Oral factor Xa inhibitors such as apixaban, edoxaban, or rivaroxaban can be used in such cases. 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: The given image shows a normal His bundle electrogram. Which of the following options indicates AV nodal conduction time?

choices.text: From wave 1 to start of wave 3
From wave 1 to start of wave 2
From wave 2 to start of wave 4
From wave 2 to start of wave 3

questions.solution:
The AV nodal conduction time corresponds with the AH interval of HBE, which extends from wave 1 (A wave) to the start of wave 2 (H wave).

His bundle electrogram (HBE):

HBE is the record of the electrical activity obtained with the catheter passed through a vein to the right side of the heart and placed close to the tricuspid valve.

It shows 3 deflections, as shown in the figure:

 

His bundle waves

Description

A

Denotes AV node activation

H

Denotes transmission through His bundle

V

Denotes ventricular depolarization 

 

With HBE and standard ECG leads, 3 intervals can be timed accurately

Interval

Recording

Corresponding event

PA interval

Time from the first appearance of atrial depolarization to the A wave in HBE

Conduction time from SA node to AV node

AH interval

From A wave to the start of H spike

AV nodal conduction time

HV interval

Time from start of H spike to start of QRS deflection in ECG

Conduction in Bundle of His and bundle branches

questions.text: A boy presents with breathlessness to the hospital. He gives a history of leg pain over the calf for a few days, for which he sought massaging from his mother, after which he developed breathlessness. Which of the following findings on the ECG would suggest a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism for this patient?
questions.solution:
The history is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis leading to pulmonary embolism.

The specific abnormality in ECG seen in pulmonary embolism is

The S1 Q3 T3 sign:

  • S wave in lead I
  • Q wave in lead III
  • Inverted T wave in lead III

S1Q3T3 is highly specific but not sensitive (meaning it is not always present).

Instead, the most common abnormality in pulmonary embolism is right ventricular (RV) strain and ischemia, which is depicted on an ECG as T-wave inversions in leads V1-V4.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male patient presents with retrosternal chest pain. On auscultation, a pericardial friction rub is present. Echocardiography reveals a small amount of pericardial fluid. The ECG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient with widespread ST elevation is acute pericarditis.

Acute pericarditis is an inflammation of the pericardium characterized by retrosternal chest pain that is aggravated by deep inspiration and supine position and relieved by sitting and leaning forward. It can be attributed to various causes like infections or inflammatory conditions like RA and SLE, or miscellaneous causes like iatrogenic, neoplasms, drugs, etc.

On auscultation, 85% of patients have a pericardial friction rub. This appears as a rough scratching sound at end of expiration when the patient is sitting and leaning forward. 

ECG findings of acute pericarditis need to be differentiated from those of myocardial infarction as they are similar.

There are four stages in the development of acute pericarditis ECG changes.

  • Stage 1: Widespread elevation of ST segments; depression of PR segment below the TP segment
  • Stage 2: ST segments return to normal after a few days
  • Stage 3: T waves become inverted
  • Stage 4: ECG returns to normal after weeks or months

Echocardiography is diagnostic for acute pericarditis. It would reveal a small amount of pericardial fluid. It can also be confirmed by CT or MRI. 

Treatment of acute pericarditis is nonspecific. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are recommended, along with bed rest.

Other options:

Option A - Myocardial infarction would not have a pericardial friction rub. In addition, the ST changes would be localized to a specific area but in pericarditis, there are widespread changes. They would also be more prominent elevations.

Option C - Cardiac tamponade is characterized by Beck's triad of hypotension, jugulo-venous distension, and muffled heart sounds. None of these are present in this patient. 

Option D - Pulmonary embolism would be characterized by tachycardia, inverted T waves (right ventricular overload) in leads V1 - V4, and S1Q3T3 pattern would be seen.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the U wave in an ECG except?

choices.text: Normally deflection is ≤1 mm and usually has the same polarity as the T wave
Prominent U waves are a marker of increased susceptibility to torsades de pointes
Abnormal increase in amplitude is seen in hyperkalemia
Occurs due to repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

questions.solution:
An abnormal increase in the amplitude of the U wave is seen in hypokalemia and not hyperkalemia.

U waves in the ECG represent the ventricular repolarization, particularly of myocytes with long action potentials (option D). The U wave is a small, rounded deflection ≤1 mm that occurs after the T wave. It usually has the same polarity as the T wave (option A). A very prominent U wave is considered a marker of increased susceptibility to torsades de pointes (option B). Abnormal increase in U-wave amplitude are most commonly due to drugs such as dofetilide, amiodarone, sotalol, and quinidine. It may also be seen in hypokalemia.

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency room with complaints of nausea, muscle weakness, and a sense of extreme fatigue. He is a known case of CKD on treatment with enalapril. His ECG is given below. What is the first step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows peaked T waves, flattened P waves, and broad QRS complexes, suggesting hyperkalemia. This patient also has chronic kidney disease and is on treatment with an ACE inhibitor, enalapril. Both of these factors are independent risk factors for hyperkalemia. The first step in the management of hyperkalemia is the administration of IV calcium gluconate.

ECG changes seen in hyperkalemia vary with the level of serum K+ (normal serum K+ is 3.5-5.5 mEq/L):

  • 5.5-6.5 mEq/L- tall, peaked T waves
  • 6.5-7.5 mEq/L- flattening of P waves
  • 7.0-8.0 mEq/L - widening of QRS complexes
  • >8.0 mEq/L - sine wave pattern of ECG

The resting membrane potential of excitable cells is close to the resting membrane potential for K+. In the resting state, there is a constant leakage of K+ out of the cell. If the K+ is higher in the extracellular environment (hyperkalemia), less K+ will leak out of the cell because the gradient is unfavorable. This increases the positive charge inside the cell, leading to the membrane potential being pushed more toward the threshold. In other words, the cell is now more excitable. 

Calcium administration counteracts this by reducing the excitability of the cells and maintaining the membrane potential at the actual resting value. Calcium is administered by intravenous infusion over 2-3 minutes with cardiac monitoring. The effect of the infusion lasts for up to 60 minutes. During this time, the steps to correct K+ levels can be taken. These steps include:

  • 10 units of IV insulin followed immediately by 50 mL 50% dextrose bolus
  • Inhaled β2 agonists such as albuterol
  • Cation exchange resins such as sodium polystyrene sulfonate and patiromer can be used for the management of both acute and chronic hyperkalemia
  • Hemodialysis is the most effective method to reduce K+ concentration

Note that intravenous bicarbonate administration does not have a role in the management of acute hyperkalemia.

questions.text: The ECG of a 62-year-old hypertensive patient is as given below. What does his ECG show?
questions.solution:
His ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). 

In this patient, the height of the S wave in V1 is 25 and the R wave in V5 is 21. The sum of the two is 46. 

ECG findings suggestive of LVH are as follows: 

  • SV1 + [RV5 or RV6] >35mm
  • RaVL + SV3 >20 mm in women and >28 mm in men
  • ST depression with T wave inversion 

The causes of LVH can be divided into pressure overload or volume overload. Examples of pressure overload are hypertension and aortic stenosis leading to concentric hypertrophy. Volume overload can occur due to valvular regurgitation leading to ventricular dilation. 

Pathological cardiac conditions leading to increased cardiac workload result in compensatory mechanisms to maintain perfusion and arterial pressure. They include increasing contractility and stroke volume (Frank-Starling law), activation of neurohormonal systems like the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, and release of hormones like norepinephrine and atrial natriuretic peptide. Myocardial adaptations can also occur resulting in cellular hypertrophy of the myocytes. 

LVH occurs due to increased mechanical work. However, the increased muscle mass has increased metabolic demands as well leading to a further increase in oxygen demand. This makes patients with LVH susceptible to ischemia and heart failure. 

Other options:

Option B - Right ventricular hypertrophy is characterized by tall R waves in lead V1, where R is bigger than the S wave, right axis deviation. ST depression and T wave inversion in right to mid-precordial leads can be present.

Option C - Acute myocardial infarction is characterized by localized ST-segment depressions or elevations with T-wave inversions. 

Option D - Acute pericarditis is characterized by widespread ST-segment elevations and T-wave inversions. 

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: Which of the following is not a finding you would expect to see in a patient with a left bundle branch block?

choices.text: Broad monophasic R wave in V5-V6

questions.solution:
RSR’ pattern in V1-3 is seen in the case of the right bundle branch block (RBBB), not the left bundle branch block (LBBB). 

ECG findings suggestive of LBBB:

  • QRS duration of >120 ms 
  • Dominant S wave in V1 with loss of R wave
  • Notched R wave and no Q wave in V6

The below image shows the characteristic changes in LBBB:

 

ECG findings suggestive of RBBB:

  • rSR’ pattern in V1-2 
  • Wide S wave in the lateral leads I, V6
  • T wave inversion in the right precordial leads and upright T waves in left precordial leads due to discordance to terminal QRS vector
  • Broad QRS complex of more than > 120 ms

The image below and the ECG show the above mentioned changes in RBBB: 

Bundle branch blocks occur due to impaired conduction in the intraventricular conduction system. This leads to the prolongation of the QRS complex by more than 120 ms. However, incomplete blocks can also occur, leading to a QRS complex duration of 110–120 ms. 

The orientation of the QRS vector depends on the branch block. In LBBB, the QRS vector is directed to the left and posteriorly. In RBBB, the QRS vector is oriented anteriorly and to the right, leading to an rSR' pattern in V1 and qRS in V6. 

RBBBs are more common in patients without structural heart disease. LBBB is associated with coronary heart disease, hypertensive heart disease, aortic valve disease, and cardiomyopathy.
